Award.AwardTitle: Building a Lake Erie Area Research Network (LEARN)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fresh water is a finite resource. Communities, environmentalists, governments, academics, and corporations are increasingly recognizing that its availability as a clean and abundant resource could introduce conflicts over its use and misuse. Because of this, the connection between water, people, energy, agriculture, and climate is an important one. Unfortunately, because stressors such as climate change, land use, and population shifts operate on a large scale, the solution sets must also be grand. Therefore, the long-term goal is to better manage and sustain Lake Erie in light of human-driven stressors by creating a consortium of field stations and their associated researchers; the consortium would be entitled, "Lake Erie Area Research Network" or "LEARN." This award will support planning activities for this network including a two-day workshop, a series of webinars, and survey work in order to establish the foundation for the LEARN consortium - a consortium of field stations, scientific equipment, and diverse researchers to address the grand challenges facing Lake Erie. For LEARN to be successful it will require (1) the involvement of diverse skill sets, (2) financial assets, (3) collaboration, and (4) communication.

Because of its mission (under NOAA and the National Sea Grant College Program) to sustain and enhance the health and wise use of Lake Erie's resources while serving as an unbiased, impartial program, the Ohio Sea Grant College Program is ideally suited to be the leader of the consortium. Ohio Sea Grant is based out of The Ohio State University, which allows the program to tap into the vast resources associated with the university. Furthermore, Ohio Sea Grant, throughout its existence, has utilized and strengthened partnerships with government, academic resources, and the private sector to address environmental, economic, and education issues using a combination of research, education, and outreach projects. Since Ohio Sea Grant is implemented at Ohio State and works closely with its scientists and administration, the university's in-house experts, laboratories, and test assets will be leveraged. When layered with the research and technical assets of other key research universities in the region (e.g., the other members of the consortium), as well as the technical acumen and innovative ideas of businesses, the LEARN consortium will provide the integrated effort needed to solve/address the grand issues facing Lake Erie, the Great Lakes, and all freshwater resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It could be argued that freshwater, a finite resource, is becoming more valuable than oil. Communities, environmentalists, governments, academics, and corporations are increasingly recognizing that its availability as a clean and abundant resource could introduce conflicts over its use and misuse. Be- cause of this, the connection between water, people, energy, agriculture, and climate is an important one. Unfortunately, because stressors like climate change, land use, and population shifts operate on a large scale, the solutions must also be grand. Therefore, our long-term goal is to better manage and sustain Lake Erie in light of human-driven stressors by creating a consortium of field stations and their associated researchers; the consortium is entitled “Lake Erie Area Re- search  Network" or LEARN. For LEARN to be successful it will require (1) the involvement of diverse skill sets, (2) tremendous assets, (3) collaboration, and (4) communication.

With this effort to create such a network, survey results, webinar insights, and workshop discussions highlighted a few key takeaways regarding Lake Erie researchers and their needs. We reached out to over 150 Lake Erie area researchers, and over 45 responded with information like their areas of research interest and their needs in their research program. With these events, network bylaws were established, membership options and benefits were discussed, five network committees were developed, and network website was created. Thus, initial members have agreed that LEARN will set out to: 1) enhance collaboration, cooperation, and communication (reduce duplicative efforts), 2) capitalize on skill sets, technologies, and methodologies of LEARN members, and 3) utilize existing equipment and facilities which will confer a cost savings across all of its member institutions.

Half of the 45+ survey respondents indicated they have 5 or less years of experience working on Lake Erie and seek networking and collaboration opportunities, issue identification, knowledge of key researchers and programs, as well as access to equipment. Survey respondents also indicated that they are from a diverse set of universities, from small institutions under 5,000 students to large institutions over 30,000 students, stressing the diverse needs of Lake Erie scientists. Furthermore, respondents indicated that grant proposal development, access to assets (i.e. equipment, lab space, sampling vessels, researcher housing), professional development opportunities, and data sharing were top needs .We also learned that we have a substantial reach with aquatic based researchers, but we will need to seek involvement from more area terrestrial researchers, as well as geologist, economists, and the private sector. With 45+ researchers providing information and feedback through the survey and also 45 attendees to the in-person workshop, area Lake Erie researchers appear to be invested in the development of LEARN. The positive feedback we have received thus far confirms that Lake Erie research consortium is needed. A network website is under development to provide LEARN researchers an easily accessible resource of the information they have expressed a need for, e.g. learning about collaboration opportunities, sampling events, workshops, etc.

LEARN is focused only on Lake Erie and its watershed, as we argue that Lake Erie is the ideal testbed/case study for the aquatic issues that are manifesting across the globe. Because of the number of people that rely on it for drinking water, recreation, and economic stability (agriculture and industry), Lake Erie draws a tremendous amount of political (restoration and research funds are being mobilized that demand wise use), research, and media attention. Lake Erie is the “Canary in the Coalmine” and has a long history of environmental issues and solutions. Lake Erie is also a fairly unique system because its three basins are very different biologically, chemically, and physically. Further, the stressors on each basin are very different; e.g., varying influence of people, industry, nutrient inputs, fish populations. Thus the methods, discussions, and solutions experienced with this diverse group on this unique system will likely be informative to researchers around the world.

The education, training and outreach efforts by LEARN institutions will likely grow exponentially when augmented with similar efforts as research asset sharing. Resources associated with duplicative efforts, where unnecessary, will be redirected to new expanded programing and efforts in keeping underrepresented students engaged. Additionally, expanding the opportunity to present Lake Erie research at other LEARN institutions that lack such infrastructure at informal education facilities, like Stone Laboratory’s Aquatic Visitor Center, is a key benefit to members of this consortium, increasing researcher opportunities to reach and inform the public with up-to-date science.

Furthermore, members agreed that LEARN should initiate projects that foster economic development, that enhance the value of Lake Erie to the state and region, and that identify solutions that can inform policy and/or inform needed behavior changes. The early members agree to work toward guiding transformational research (inform policy and behavior), not just advance scientific understanding.
